title: Meta Removes News From Platform in Canada
description: A Canadian law that will require tech companies to compensate domestic publishers has led Meta to start blocking news articles on its social networks.

title: Russia’s Pro-War Bloggers Are Suddenly Sniping Among Themselves
description: A new tone has set in among the uninhibited military bloggers, whose support for the invasion has given them unusual powers to speak out.

title: Winter Heat Wave Grips Chile, Argentina and Other South American Countries
description: An unusual winter heat wave has brought record high temperatures to cities across Argentina, Chile and Paraguay this week, triggering concerns about the impacts of climate change.

title: Seiichi Morimura, 90, Who Exposed Japanese Wartime Atrocities, Dies
description: In a widely read book, he detailed gruesome biological experiments on people at a secret Imperial Army site in occupied China before and during World War II.

title: Two U.S. Navy Sailors Charged With Helping Chinese
description: Prosecutors said the two sailors in California gave Chinese intelligence officers U.S. military secrets and sensitive information.

title: Poland and Lithuania Warn Against ‘Provocations’ From Wagner in Belarus
description: The notice came a few days after two helicopters bearing Belarusian flags violated Polish airspace.

title: Trump’s Jury for Jan. 6 Trial: A City That Remembers the Capitol Attack
description: Jurors drawn from among the residents of the District of Columbia will be called on to decide the fate of the former president.

title: Rishi Sunak Home Scaled by Greenpeace Protesters in Britain
description: The incursion by opponents of oil drilling raised concerns about the security of the British leader and his family.

title: Colombia Rebel Group ELN and Government Begin Cease-Fire
description: A six-month truce began on Thursday between the government and the largest remaining insurgency, the far-left group known as the National Liberation Army.

title: 14 Injured in Stabbing and Car Rampage Near Seoul
description: Less than a month after another mass stabbing, 13 victims were sent to the hospital in a similar incident that also included five people being hit by a car. The episode is being treated as a “terrorist act.”

title: Hundreds Fall Ill From Heat at World Scout Jamboree in South Korea
description: As the country endures its hottest summer in years, at least 125 people were hospitalized and many others were treated for symptoms during baking conditions at the World Scout Jamboree.

title: Australia Will Return Looted Sculptures to Cambodia
description: A centuries-old Buddhist sculpture was taken from a rural area in Cambodia nearly 30 years ago. It was later sold with two other statues to the National Gallery of Australia.

title: Russia-Ukraine War: Ukraine Boosts Production of Ammunition as War Depletes Global Supply
description: Ukraine has long been in danger of running out of ammunition.

title: The Art of Telling Forbidden Stories in China
description: Many writers are looking for ways to capture the everyday realities that the government keeps hidden — sometimes at their own peril.

title: Thursday Briefing
description: The future of U.S. politics after Donald Trump’s indictment.

title: Niger Coup: Here’s What to Know
description: Amid an unpredictable military coup, neighboring countries have threatened to go to war — some to scuttle the coup, and others to ensure its success.

title: Ukrainians Shun a Church Seen as a Kremlin Tool
description: The village parishioners’ decision to oust their priest reflects a broader push within Ukraine to reduce the influence of an Orthodox church that answers to Moscow.

title: VanMoof’s Bankruptcy Worries Owners of Electric Bikes
description: VanMoof’s sleek electric bikes attracted fans, but the Dutch company’s demise has left owners unable to get repairs and worried that app-enabled functions may stop working.

title: South Korean Ferry Disaster Figure Yoo Hyuk-kee Is Extradited
description: Yoo Hyuk-kee’s family company ran the Sewol ferry, whose sinking off the South Korean coast left hundreds dead. Prosecutors have charged Mr. Yoo, a U.S. resident, with embezzlement.
